An effective and highly selective protocol has been realized for the synthesis of asymmetric organic carbonates using dimethyl carbonate (DMC) as a reactant and solvent. Herein, the performance of CeO2 nanostructures with different morphology was explored in the carbonate interchange reaction (CIR) of alcohols to synthesize asymmetric organic carbonates. The CeO2 nano-catalyst with rod morphology having the highest oxygen vacancy enabled remarkable enhancement in the conversion, to our knowledge this is superior to most of the reported heterogeneous catalytic materials. The CeO2-r (r-rods) is used as low as <0.8 mol% with respect to the limiting reagent (alcohol). The CeO2 characterization data revealed the intriguing properties such as exposed active sites, defect density, coordination state of surface atoms, and reducibility of the catalytic materials are the contributing factors in realizing the highest catalytic activity. The CeO2 was recovered by a simple centrifugation and used in more than four recycles with consistent catalytic activity. The work conducted herein intensifies the utilization of bio-alcohols and CO2 derived DMC for the sustainable synthesis of organic carbonates that have immense applications in various sectors. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Guerbet reaction Organic carbonates CeO2 Bio-alcohols Carbonate interchange reaction Bio-ethanol Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction The sound utilization of biomass resources for the production of chemicals and fuels is a major challenge yet attractive approach to attain carbon neutrality. These strategies offer the unforeseen applications of the products, which are obtained from the biomass resources [1–4]. In this context, bioethanol represents the sustainable, renewable, and greener alternate to fossil resources to thwart the augmenting environmental concerns aroused from the usage of non-renewable feedstocks [5]. Presently, bioethanol is the major contributor of biofuels that accounts for 90 % of world's biofuels production. It is a promising platform chemical from which a wide variety of chemicals, fuels, and platform molecules can be synthesized [6,7]. In this direction, a variety of catalytic materials are reported for the production of 1-butanol & higher alcohols from bioethanol through Guerbet process [7–10] (ESI Table S1). The guerbet reaction involves the coupling of short chain alcohols. It is the key reaction in upgrading of short chain alcohols to higher alcohols [10]. These approaches enable us to synthesize the longer chained alcohols, thanks to Marcel guerbet [11–13]. These bioethanol derived alcohols offer promising opportunities for the sustainable synthesis of organic carbonates through CIR/carboxymethylation using DMC and this approach evades the utilization of highly toxic & corrosive chemicals like phosgene [14]. Dimethyl carbonate is becoming a popular reagent and is ecologically safe substitute to highly toxic and corrosive chemicals like halomethanes (CH3X, X= Cl, Br, I), dimethyl sulfate (DMS), and COCl2 (phosgene) in alkylation and carbonate interchange reactions respectively [15–20]. Lately, a sizeable body of literature published on the atom economical & green synthesis of DMC using abundant and inexpensive CO2 as the renewable C1 feedstock [15,21–23]. The synthesis of DMC using methanol & CO2 is the greenest among the available strategies and is free from the virulent starting materials and by-products [24,25]. In this scenario, the utilization of chemicals derived from bioethanol (higher alcohols) and carbon dioxide (DMC) represents the sustainable approach for the greatly acknowledged organic carbonates synthesis. These organic carbonates (OCs) have got extensive applications in fine chemicals, pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, polymer synthesis, biofuels, lubricants, herbicides, solvents, and so forth [26–30]. The green credentials, flexible reactivity, reduced environmental footprints, and excellent commercial applications of organic carbonates have been key aspects to make it a vibrant area of research [31]. The enormous research efforts dedicated for the sustainable production of OCs, which resulted in number of publications in recent years. The carboxymethylation of biomass-derived alcohols using DMC has turned out as an important reaction as it sustainably produces the organic carbonates. There are several catalysts such as zeolites [32], oxides [26,30], polymers [19], mesoporous silica [33], and metal complexes [34,35] investigated for this transformation. Noticeably, the pioneering work conducted by Jin Saimeng et al. explores the catalytic activity of various acid catalysts like H2SO4, FeCl3, PTSA (p-toluenesulfonic acid), and AlCl3. These catalysts demonstrated complete conversion of primary alcohols with moderated conversion of secondary alcohols [14,36]. Ramesh et al. explored the spray dried NaAlO2 and NaAlO2/TiO2 catalysts for the carboxymethylation of range of alcohols and these materials demonstrated an excellent catalytic activity in achieving good yields of respective carbonates [37,38]. Chevella D. and co-workers investigated the nanocrystalline ZSM-5 and were successful in achieving >95 % yield of asymmetric organic carbonates when primary alcohols are used. Lately, Kempanna et al. employed polymer-based catalyst (MP-SO3H) for the efficient transformation of bio-alcohols under mild conditions. Wherein, authors developed a sustainable strategy to exemplify high (>95 %) conversion of bio-alcohols to OCs [19]. Furthermore, several other catalytic materials explored for this transformation [34,39–42] are summarised in ESI Table S2. In spite of number of publications, many systems saddled with the intense reaction conditions, complex synthetic approaches, catalyst recovery and prolonged reaction times. To circumvent the limitations associated with the reported catalysts, it is appealing to explore a new catalyst that evades the problems of reported materials. In this contribution, we have developed an effective, highly selective protocol for the synthesis of OCs using DMC as a reactant and solvent. This protocol is characterized by its practicality, carbon neutrality, sustainable nature, and the great potential of CeO2 in transforming number of alcohols. Lately, the CeO2 has been extensively studied as catalyst or catalytic support in various organic transformations owing to its attractive properties [43–47]. The properties of CeO2, which influence the catalytic activity such as exposed active sites, specific surface area (SSA), defect density, surface reducibility, morphology, and coordination state of surface atoms, have been explored extensively [48–50]. It is well documented in the literature that the above-mentioned properties can be altered by adopting the apt synthesis conditions. Herein, we have synthesised the CeO2 nano structures with different morphology by adopting the different hydrothermal treatment conditions and demarcated the intriguing properties that are responsible for impressive catalytic activity using different analytical techniques. These materials are harnessed as the catalysts for the carboxymethylation of various alcohols. The CeO2-r demonstrated the good catalytic activity (>95 % conversion with >96 % selectivity) which is one of the best available reports on the carboxymethylation of alcohols. This strategy may open up the new opportunities to transform biomass-derived alcohols into useful chemicals in the near future. Experimental Chemicals Chemicals used in the carbonate interchange reaction were used as received from the commercial venders. Ce(NO3)3 ·6H2O (Laba Chemie, 99.9 %), NaOH pellets (Merck, >97 %), CH3OH (Merck, 99.0 %), n-butanol (Merck, 99.0 %), 2-methyl propyl alcohol (Merck, 99.0 %), tert‑butanol (Merck, 99.0 %), n-propanol (Merck, 99.0 %), ethanol (Changshu Hong sheng Fine Chemicals, 99.9 %), 1-hexanol (Avra chemicals, 98.0 %), dimethyl carbonate (Laba Chemie, 99.0 %), 1-octanol (Avra chemicals), Isopropyl alcohol (SDFCL, 99.0 %), benzyl alcohol (Merck, 99.0 %), sulphuric acid (H2SO4) (Merck, 95–98 %) and cyclohexanol (SDFCL, 95.0 %). Materials The H-BEA zeolite having silica to alumina ratio of 25 was purchased from the Nankai, china. Prior to the reaction, NH4+ form of zeolite was transformed to H + form by calcining it at 540 °C for 6 h with 5 °C/minute ramp rate under static air. The MgO is obtained from the commercial suppliers and used after calcination at 600 °C for 6 h. Amberlyst-15 was obtained from the Alfa Aesar and used in the CIR after drying it at 120 °C for 2 h. The sulphated zirconia was synthesized by following the reported procedure [51,52]. Synthesis of ceo2 nano structures The CeO2 nanocatalysts with different morphology are synthesized by following the reported literature [48]. Briefly, 0.001 mol of Ce(NO3)3 6H2O was dissolved in 2.5 mL of distilled water. Then, 0.12 mol of NaOH was dissolved in 17.5 mL of distilled water in a separate beaker. Both the solutions were stirred at room temperature for 10 min to ensure the complete dissolution of precursor and precipitant (NaOH). Subsequently, the precipitant is added dropwise to the Ce(NO3)3 solution over the period of 30 min. The formation of colloidal solution [Ce(OH)3] specifies the hydrolysis of Ce(NO3)3. The hydrolysed material is hydrothermally treated for 24 h at 180 °C in a Teflon-lined autoclave (50 mL) provided with stainless steel jacket under static condition. Afterwards, the hydrothermal synthesis reactor was cooled to ambient conditions, to eliminate the unreacted precursors and precipitant the material was washed repeatedly with water, and ethanol by means of centrifugation until the supernatant was neutral. The final material obtained was dried at 80 °C for 8 h in a hot air oven followed by calcination at 600 °C for 5 h under static air. The material is designated as CeO2-nanocubes (CeO2-c). Likewise, the CeO2-nanorods (CeO2-r) were synthesized by hydrothermal treatment at 90 °C for 24 h. To compare the catalytic activity of CeO2, other conventional materials such as MgO, H-BEA (25), Amberlyst-15, and sulphated zirconia are screened for the CIR of n-butanol with dimethyl carbonate under identical reaction conditions. Characterization As synthesized materials (CeO2) were characterized by different analytical techniques to define the properties of the catalysts. The methodology adopted for the analysis and details of the instruments used are given in the ESI Section 1. Catalytic activity study The carbonate interchange reaction (CIR) of alcohols with DMC was conducted in a pre-dried round-bottomed glass reactor (25 ml) equipped with condenser (maintained at 6–8 °C) and a thermometer. In brief, 6.0 mmol of alcohol and 75.0 mmol of dimethyl carbonate were taken in a round-bottomed flask along with 157 mg of catalyst. The flask was immersed in the pre-heated oil bath (90 °C) provided with the magnetic stirrer. The reaction was performed at 90 °C for the desired interval of time (24 h) with constant stirring. After completion of the reaction, the flask was immersed in ice-cold water and the catalyst was separated by centrifugation. To monitor the progress of the reaction, the reaction mixtures were analysed by gas chromatograph (Shimadzu-2014) provided with Stabilwax column (0.25 mm I.D., 30 m length, and 0.25 μm film thickness), and flame ionization detector (FID). The injector port and detector temperatures were set to 240 °C and initial column temperature is kept at 80 °C. Then initial column temperature (80 °C) is increased to 240 °C with the ramp rate of 10 °C/min and 5 min hold at this temperature. The conversion of alcohol and selectivity to asymmetric carbonates were calculated based on the conversion of the limiting reagent used (alcohol). Alcohol conversion ( % ) = Initial moles of alcohol − Final moles of alcohol Initial moles of alcohol × 100 Selectivity ( % ) = Moles of desired product Moles of alcohol converted × 100 Regeneration of catalyst The catalysts harnessed (CeO2-r) in the carboxymethylation of alcohol with DMC were collected back from reaction mixture, washed repeatedly using distilled water and ethanol by centrifugation. The reactants/products free material is dried at 80 °C for 8 h in a hot air oven and calcined at 600 °C for 5 h in a muffle furnace to ensure the complete removal of left out reactants/products. The calcined material (CeO2) is used in the next catalytic run for the CIR of alcohols with DMC. Results and discussion Catalyst characterization The powder XRD patterns of different morphologies of CeO2 are presented in Fig. 1 . All the diffraction patterns of CeO2 mixed, cubic and nanorod are correspond to the cubic fluorite phase of CeO2 (PDF-ICDD 34–0394). The diffraction pattern of nanorod exhibits broader peaks than mixed and cubic morphology and crystallite size calculated from Scherrer equation. Using Eq. (1), the crystallite size was calculated for all three different morphologies of the CeO2. The crystallite size decreased in the order of mixed-phase (12.2 nm) > cube (11.8 nm) > rod (9.4 nm) by influencing the formation of oxygen vacancies, which contributes to a change in the oxidation of Ce4+ to Ce3+ [53,54] (1) D = K λ β c o s θ Where, D = Crystallite size (nm), K=0.9 (Scherrer constant), λ = 0.15418(wavelength of X-ray), β = FWHM (radians), θ = peak position (radians) The surface area of different morphologies of CeO2 catalysts were obtained by the N2 adsorption-desorption analysis. Isotherms of the mixed, cube and rod shape of CeO2 shows type IV that is characteristic of typical mesoporous structure (Fig. 2 ) [55–57]. The surface area of mixed, cube, and rod morphologies of CeO2 are 10.4, 21.7, and 83.2 m2/g respectively (Table 1 ). The surface area of different CeO2 morphologies was associated with the size of their crystallites. Surface area increased in the order of mixed < cube < rod. This could be because of a decrease in crystallite size to some extent, which influences the creation of more oxygen vacant site of Ce3+ in the catalyst. The TEM image of mixed CeO2 catalyst with spheroidal and cuboidal morphologies is shown in Fig. 3 a. Fig. 3b displays a HRTEM image of cubic CeO2 with an average particle size of 40 nm. CeO2 nanorods with an average length of 170 nm are shown in Fig. 3c and d. The TEM analysis of CeO2 catalysts showed that the adopted synthesis conditions exclusively produce the cube and rod morphologies. The reduction behavior of different morphologies of CeO2 was investigated by the temperature reduction technique. CeO2 exhibits two different types of reduction peaks. The peak below 500 °C belongs to surface oxygen, while the peak above 700 °C corresponds to lattice oxygen [58]. Fig. 4 shows that H2 consumption of surface oxygen increases in the order of mixed oxide < cubic < rod. This indicates that the CeO2 rod possesses the highest amount of surface oxygen, which is associated with the oxygen deficiency site formed by OCe3+. The amount and nature of basic and oxygen vacancy sites of as synthesized CeO2 materials were determined by temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) analysis (Fig. 5 ). The analysis was performed using CO2 as a probe molecule. Lewis acidic oxygen vacancy sites are oxygen-deficient sites that can interact with nonbonding electrons in the O atom of CO2 via Lewis acid-base interactions [59,60]. Theoretical studies suggest that the oxygen-deficient site on the surface of the catalyst allows one of the O atoms of CO2 to be inserted into the oxygen vacancy site, resulting in a bent CO2 [61,62]. Hence CO2 molecule chemisorb on the Lewis acidic oxygen vacancy sites on the surface of catalyst, stabilizing the CO2 by filling of one of its oxygens in it [56,63]. As a result, CO2-TPD determines the total amount of basic and oxygen vacancy sites. The CO2 chemisorption of mixed-phase, cube and rod showed 0.031, 0.054 and 0.134 mmol/g respectively (Table 1). The XPS spectra of Ce 3d for various CeO2 morphologies are shown in Fig. 6 . The spin-orbital splitting of Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2 can be deconvoluted into eight peaks, which correspond to the U and V characters [60]. Ce3+ state of 3d104f1 are attributed to U' and V' whereas Ce4+ state of 3d104f0 are attribute to U, U'', U''', V, V'', and V''' [65]. The surface oxygen vacancy on CeO2 is created by Ce3+-O bond whereas lattice oxygen is formed by Ce4+- O bond [66]. The percentage of Ce3+ concentration on different morphologies of CeO2 is calculated using the ratio between Ce3+ area (U' and V') and total area of Ce3+ (U’ and V') and Ce4+ (U, U'', U''', V, V'', and V''') (Eq. (1)). (2) C [ C e 3 + ] % = A C e 3 + A C e 3 + + A C e 4 + x 100 The surface concentration of Ce3+ are 13.6, 16.2 and 21.2 % for mixed phase, cube and rod morphologies of CeO2 respectively (Table 2 ). This finding suggests that rod morphology of CeO2 has a higher Ce3+ concentration on the surface. O1s spectra of CeO2 is deconvoluted into two peaks which are assigned to surface oxygen and lattice oxygen (Fig. 7 ). The binding energy of lattice oxygen is 529.3 eV while the binding energy of surface oxygen is 531.2 eV [67]. As a result, Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies can be related to oxygen species on the surface. The quantitative percentage of surface oxygen species for mixed-phase, cube, and rod morphologies of CeO2 is 40.6 51.8, and 60.7 % respectively. Hence, the rod morphology of CeO2 containing the maximum percentage of surface oxygen species. These findings are consistent with the Ce3+ concentration in the catalyst. The XPS, TPR and CO2 chemisorption characterization results showed that CeO2 nanorod has contains more oxygen vacancy than mixed-phase and cubic morphologies. Catalytic performance Screening study The thoroughly characterized materials are employed for the carboxymethylation of alcohols. Firstly, the reaction was performed in absence of catalyst wherein there is no conversion of n-butanol observed (Table 3 , entry 1). The observed phenomenon confirms that the reaction is truly catalytic and does not proceed in the absence of catalytic material. In order to find out the efficient catalytic material for the DMC mediated carboxymethylation of butanol, as synthesized catalysts such as CeO2-nano-spheres (CeO2-s), CeO2-nano-cubes (CeO2-c), and CeO2-nano-rods (CeO2-r) have been investigated. Additionally, the reported catalysts such as HBEA and commercial MgO have been screened. The results of catalytic activity of all the materials screened for the carboxymethylation have been summarised in Table 3. Under the similar reaction conditions CeO2-s has been screened for the carboxymethylation wherein the material demonstrated the lower conversion of alcohol (26 %) (Table 3, entry 2). In contrast to CeO2-s, the CeO2-c and CeO2-r exemplified the comparatively good and excellent conversions respectively. Among, the CeO2-r demonstrated the highest catalytic activity compared the nano-spheres and cubes, which is mainly attributed to the highest oxygen vacancy achieved with the rod morphology (Table 3, entry 3). The observed catalytic activity of CeO2 catalysts is in accord with the number of active sites present in the materials. Additionally, it was observed that the catalytic activity of HBEA is very low and demonstrated less than 2 % conversion and MgO showed the good catalytic activity of about 20 % conversion with high selectivity (Table 3, entry 6). However, these materials are less potent in contrast to best catalyst (CeO2-r). As observed in the initial screening study, the catalytic activity of CeO2-r is superior to all the materials employed and demonstrated 90 % conversion within 10 h of reaction time. These observations suggest that the material with more defect sites will be a good candidate to achieve high selectivity and conversions. The CeO2-rod catalyst is used for the further investigation in the controlled experiments. Effect of mole ratio To achieve the maximum catalytic activity of CeO2-r, the various reaction parameters have been studied. Among them, the mole ratio between reactants is one of the important parameter that plays a decisive role to achieve good conversion and selectivity. Herein, the mole ratio between reactants (butanol and DMC) was varied and its impact on the product distribution was studied for CIR using 45 wt.% of CeO2-r under similar reaction conditions. The experimental observations showed that mole ratio between the reactants has substantial influence on the catalytic activity of CeO2-r and results of mole ratio investigation are presented in Fig. 8 . As expected, we observed the lower catalytic activity of CeO2-r at 1:2.5 mole ratio. However, at higher mole ratio (1:7.5) we witnessed a significant improvement in the alcohol conversion (96 %). The phenomenon attributed to the excess availability of carboxymethylating agent i.e. DMC. Nevertheless, the further addition of DMC to achieve the 1:10 and 1:12.5 mole ratio had minor detrimental effect on the catalytic activity and showed trivial loss in the alcohol conversion. The slight drop in the alcohol conversion might ascribed to its dilution instigated by the excess DMC. Wherein, the adsorption of limiting reagent if prevented and leads to reduction in the catalytic activity. From this study, it was observed that 1:7.5 is the optimum ratio to exhibit highest catalytic activity. Effect of catalyst dosage The influence of catalyst quantity on the product distribution was studied by varying the dosages of catalyst with respect to the limiting agent (Alcohol) using CeO2-r catalyst. The catalyst concentration was increased from 20 to 45 wt.% with respect to butanol. It was observed that the butanol conversion was progressively increased from 82 to 94 % by increasing the catalyst concentration 20 to 35 wt.% at 90 °C under atmospheric pressure. The observed enhancement in the alcohol conversion is attributed to the higher amount of active sites added at 35 wt.% catalyst dosage, which is responsible for converting more alcohol molecules. At this catalyst dosage, the activity is maximum and observed the highest conversion of butanol (94 %) with good selectivity to the butyl methyl carbonate (98 %). However, the further increment in the catalyst concentration to 45 wt.% did not show significant improvement in the alcohol conversion. Therefore, the influence of catalyst dosage study evinced that 35 wt.% is the optimum catalyst quantity to achieve maximum conversion and good selectivity to butyl methyl carbonate (BMC). The results of catalysts dosage investigation are presented in Fig. 9 . Effect of reaction time To investigate the influence of time on the catalytic activity of CeO2-r in CIR, the reaction was stopped at different time and samples are analysed by gas chromatograph (GC). Wherein, six independent batch reactions were conducted under identical reaction conditions to avoid the loss of vapours while withdrawing the aliquots of reaction mixture. The reaction conditions employed and results of effect of time are presented in Fig. 10 . At 2.5 hrs of reaction time, CeO2-r exemplified 47 % alcohol conversion with excellent selectivity to butyl methyl carbonate (95 %). To amplify the alcohol conversion and selectivity, the reaction time has been increased from 2.5 to 12.5 hrs that results in the gradual increase in the alcohol conversion from 47 to 98 %. Nevertheless, the slight increase in the butyl methyl carbonate selectivity has been observed (95 % to 98 %). Further continuation of reaction beyond 12.5 hrs did not show any significant improvement in the catalytic activity. From the experimental results of influence of time, the 12.5 h is the optimal time to deliver the good yield of the desired product. The results observed herein presented CeO2-r as a potential candidate, which expediently delivers the high yield of asymmetric organic carbonates under short period in contrast to many reported materials. Leaching study The heterogeneity or resistance towards the active sites leaching under the course of reaction is a crucial factor that delineate the real efficacy of given catalyst in any chemical transformation. Herein, a hot filtration experiment was conducted to check the leached active sites under the experimental conditions [catalyst concentration (CeO2-r, 35 wt.%), mole ratio (1:7.5), and temperature (90 °C)]. The catalytic material was filtered off after 2.5 h of reaction time, aliquot of a reaction mixture has been analysed by GC and material demonstrated 47 % conversion of butanol with good selectivity towards butyl methyl carbonate. The observed phenomenon evinced the efficacy of CeO2-r catalyst that exemplified 47 % conversion of alcohol within 2.5 h of reaction time. Later, the reaction mixture without catalyst has been treated under the above-mentioned reaction conditions. Then aliquots of reaction mixture were taken at different times (5, 7.5, 10 and 12.5 h). Herein, we did not observe any significant variation in the initial conversion of alcohol and it remained at 47 % (Fig. 11 ). This indicates that there is no leaching of actives sites into the reaction medium, CeO2-r is resistant towards the leaching and reaction is strictly heterogeneous in nature. Recycle study The recycle experiments were conducted for CeO2-r catalyst under optimised reaction conditions (Fig. 12 ). Typically, after each catalytic run, the CeO2-r is collected by centrifugation, washed, dried and calcined. Subsequently, the calcined material used in the next run under similar reaction conditions as in the fresh run. The study presented CeO2-r as a potential candidate that retained its original catalytic activity up to five recycles (Fig. 12). Additionally, the recycled catalyst is characterized by XRD, BET and TPD analysis. Despite of being recycled number of times, the material retained its physicochemical properties as fresh catalyst with consistent results. The CeO2-r has the excellent recycling efficiency with good resistance towards the leaching of active sites that can be used for atom efficient upgrading of biomass-derived alcohols. Substrate scope study The resilience of the protocol developed herein was explored for the number of (1°, 2°, 3°, & aromatic) alcohols having different carbon chain length and carbon atoms. The most active catalyst (CeO2-r) is used in the substrate scope study under optimised reaction conditions. The CIR of all the alcohols were carried out at 90 °C with 1:7.5 mole ratio, 35 wt.% catalyst concentration, and for 12.5 hrs of reaction time. The results of CIR of all the alcohols are summarised in the Table 4 . The catalytic material CeO2-r is versatile and offers >98 % conversion of the 1° alcohols with exclusive selectivity towards the asymmetric organic carbonates (>96 %) under optimised reaction conditions (Table 4, entry 1–5). The CeO2-r demonstrated the moderate conversion of 2° alcohols and we have not observed any conversion of 3° alcohols when reacted with DMC. The observed phenomenon might be attributed to the steric hindrance when secondary and tert‑alcohols are used (Table 4, entry 6–8). Additionally, the good conversion of aromatic alcohol was observed over the CeO2-r catalyst under optimised reaction conditions (Table 4, entry 9). The CeO2-r is remarkably versatile in nature that can transform various primary, secondary, & aromatic alcohols into useful organic carbonates. The results observed over the CeO2-r catalyst is in accord with the reported literature on the carboxymethylation of alcohols with DMC. Comparison of catalytic activity of CeO2-r catalyst with the various catalyst systems reported literature is given in the Table S2. Spent catalyst characterization The spent material was recovered by centrifugation after the end of the reaction, washed using water and ethanol and characterized by different techniques such as XRD, BET, TPD. The powder XRD patterns of spent CeO2-r is shown in Fig. S1. The diffraction pattern of spent CeO2 nanorod is similar to fresh catalyst and correspond to the cubic fluorite phase of CeO2 (PDF-ICDD 34–0394). The surface area of spent CeO2-r was obtained by N2-sorption analysis. Isotherm of spent CeO2-r is in accord with the fresh catalyst and shows type IV isotherm that corroborate the characteristic of mesoporous structure (Fig. S2). Additionally, the surface area of spent catalyst is matchable with the fresh catalyst (Table S3). The temperature programmed desorption (TPD) analysis of spent catalyst demonstrated the similar TPD profile with matchable amount of chemisorbed CO2 molecules (Table S3). Conclusion In summary, CeO2 nano-catalysts having different morphology were prepared hydrothermally and harnessed as catalysts for the sustainable synthesis of asymmetric organic carbonates. Among them, the CeO2 catalyst having rod morphology (CeO2-r) with highest oxygen vacancy exemplified an excellent catalytic activity (>95 % conversion with >96 % selectivity) that is far superior to most of the reported catalysts. The XRD, XPS, TEM and TPR analysis specified the exposed 111 and 110 planes of CeO2 induced by the rod morphology have an important role in obtaining high oxygen vacancy in the material. The systematic investigation of effect of morphology and influence of reaction parameters have emphasized CeO2-r as a potential candidate for the carboxymethylation of various alcohols. It is observed that the intriguing properties such as exposed active sites, defect density, coordination state of surface atoms, and reducibility plays a crucial role in achieving the unmatchable catalytic activity of CeO2-r catalyst. The physicochemical properties traced by material characterization have showed good correlation with the observed catalytic activity. This versatile approach expediently delivers the greatly acknowledged asymmetric organic carbonates, which have numerous applications in various sectors. The highlights of this protocol are not limited to impressive catalytic activity, mild reaction conditions, and sustainable strategy. Furthermore, the material exemplified good recycling efficiency with consistent results until five recycles and demonstrated the resistance towards the leaching of active sites under employed reaction conditions. The carboxymethylation of alcohols using CeO2 nano-rods is in accord with the atom economical, sustainable, and environmentally benign synthesis of asymmetric organic carbonates without generating inorganic salts as the by-products. The environmental friendliness, sustainability, and impressive efficiency have spotlighted CeO2-r as the potential candidate for the synthesis of OCs. coredata.dc:description: An effective and highly selective protocol has been realized for the synthesis of asymmetric organic carbonates using dimethyl carbonate (DMC) as a reactant and solvent. Herein, the performance of CeO2 nanostructures with different morphology was explored in the carbonate interchange reaction (CIR) of alcohols to synthesize asymmetric organic carbonates. The CeO2 nano-catalyst with rod morphology having the highest oxygen vacancy enabled remarkable enhancement in the conversion, to our knowledge this is superior to most of the reported heterogeneous catalytic materials. The CeO2-r (r-rods) is used as low as <0.8 mol% with respect to the limiting reagent (alcohol). The CeO2 characterization data revealed the intriguing properties such as exposed active sites, defect density, coordination state of surface atoms, and reducibility of the catalytic materials are the contributing factors in realizing the highest catalytic activity. The CeO2 was recovered by a simple centrifugation and used in more than four recycles with consistent catalytic activity. The work conducted herein intensifies the utilization of bio-alcohols and CO2 derived DMC for the sustainable synthesis of organic carbonates that have immense applications in various sectors.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of morphology and their oxygen vacancies of nanostructured CeO2 catalyst for carboxymethylation of biomass-derived alcohols
